intro: Conopodium assyriacum, commonly known as Assyrian bladdercamp, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Apiaceae. It is characterized by its erect, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers arranged in umbels. The plant produces distinctive, inflated fruit capsules that resemble bladders, giving it its common name. It is native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia, often found in rocky or dry habitats. Conopodium assyriacum is typically herbaceous, with alternate, pinnately divided leaves.
